article.description:
Diana Taurasi hit two 3-pointers in the final 2:39 when Connecticut clung to a one-point lead, and the top-ranked
Huskies escaped with a 72-69 victory Sunday over Southern California.
article.headline: Taurasi leads Huskies' escape from USC
article.linkText: Downtown Diana: UConn survives on Taurasi's 3s
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Connecticut has trailed in the second half of
games six times since the 2001-02 season. The Huskies only lost
once, so forgive them for feeling cocky when threatened with
defeat.

Diana Taurasi hit two 3-pointers in the final 2:39 when
Connecticut clung to a one-point lead, and the top-ranked Huskies
escaped with a 72-69 victory Sunday over Southern California.

"I knew we'd get back in it. We're mentally strong," said
Barbara Turner, who added 19 points. "A lot of teams wouldn't have
been able to bear down and win a game like this."

The Huskies' nearly three-year regular-season winning streak was
in jeopardy until Taurasi scored their final nine points. She
finished with 26 after the Huskies trailed by 15 points in the
first half.

"I don't know how many teams would have been able to do what we
did," UConn coach Geno Auriemma said. "It looks like Diana bailed
us out again. I don't care if she hasn't made any shots. The shots
she takes in the last five minutes are going in."

The Huskies extended their road winning streak to 31 games in
front of a noisy crowd bolstered by Taurasi's family and friends.
She's from nearby Chino, where the team dined at her family's home
Saturday night.

Rachel Woodward's game-tying 3-point attempt hit the rim and
bounced away at the buzzer.

"We're not doing the gutty little Trojan thing here," USC
coach Chris Gobrecht said. "We were a little too content to be in
the game with them. We certainly didn't play as well down the
stretch as we needed to beat a team that talented."

The Huskies (6-0) had defeated their first five opponents by an
average of 33.2 points, but had their hands full against the
Trojans.

"The first half we were down, but there was never a sense of
urgency," Taurasi said. "We're just not going to give up. We
showed a lot of character. It's going to help us down the road."

Connecticut led 63-62 when Taurasi stripped Eshaya Murphy of the
ball and hit a 3-pointer. Taurasi had missed three straight shots
before she hit from long range to give Connecticut a 66-62 lead
with 2:39 remaining.

Murphy hit a 3-pointer and Jamie Hagiya made two free throws to
draw the Trojans to 72-69. Maria Conlon missed two free throws for
UConn to create the last-second suspense.

Ebony Hoffman scored 15 points before fouling out late and
Murphy added 13 points for USC (1-3).

"We did well, but we could have won the game," Hoffman said.
"We lost focus a little bit and we paid for it. It should never
have come down to the last shot."

Taurasi scored seven of the Huskies' first 13 points as they
took a seven-point lead. The Trojans launched a 31-9 run on
consecutive 3-pointers by Hoffman and Murphy that gave them a 37-22
lead with 2:48 remaining in the first half.

USC hit six 3-pointers during the spurt in which the Huskies
committed eight of their 12 turnovers, including three by Taurasi.

"They're so physical in their defense and that set us back,"
Auriemma said. "It took a long time for us to find a little bit of
an offensive groove. It was hard to keep them off the boards. We're
a lot of things, but physically we're not very big."

Connecticut recovered quickly, outscoring the Trojans 13-4 to
close the half trailing 38-33. Conlon hit a 3-pointer with six
seconds remaining, then USC's Chloe Kerr turned the ball over and
Turner stunned USC by hitting a basket at the buzzer.

"They made every shot," Conlon said. "They were relentless on
the boards in the first half and they kept getting the putback."

The announced crowd of 6,172 at the Sports Arena was USC's
seventh-largest ever. The Trojans lost their third home opener.
They were beaten by UNLV in 1989 and San Diego State in 1996.
